content.source_insight: This sets Zebracorp's baseline for background IPR.
content.text: As for the background IPRs, Zebracorp will generally only require a license to use such background IP.

content.verbatim_text: In case the development work includes the implementation of any Zebracorp proprietary items, Zebracorp should retain IPR ownership to such proprietary items as default, without any license to the supplier.
content.plain_text: If development work involves Zebracorp proprietary items, Zebracorp should, by default, retain IPR ownership of these items without granting any license to the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This is paramount for protecting Zebracorp's core, unique IP. Granting a license to the supplier for Zebracorp's proprietary items would undermine Zebracorp's competitive advantage and control.
content.conditions: Applies when development work includes the implementation of any Zebracorp proprietary items.
content.justification: The text uses 'should retain IPR ownership... as default, without any license,' and explains why it 'cannot permit or allow the supplier to sell'.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains full control and exclusivity over its proprietary items.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier does not receive a license to Zebracorp's proprietary items.
content.source_insight: This is a strong protective measure for Zebracorp's unique IP.
content.text: In case the development work includes the implementation of any Zebracorp proprietary items, Zebracorp should retain IPR ownership to such proprietary items as default, without any license to the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: It is advisable to avoid jointly owned intellectual property rights. This is particularly true if the development work/collaboration can result in patentable inventions.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should avoid jointly owned intellectual property rights, especially if the development work could result in patentable inventions.
content.expert_insight: Joint ownership often leads to complex management, exploitation, and enforcement issues, particularly for patentable inventions. Avoiding it simplifies future commercialization and reduces legal risks.
content.conditions: Applies to intellectual property rights generated through collaborative development, especially if patentable inventions may result.
content.justification: The text uses 'It is advisable to avoid' and explains the 'difficulties' and 'complications' of joint ownership.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp avoids future complexities and potential disputes over IPR exploitation.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier may not be able to pursue joint ownership.
content.source_insight: This is a strong recommendation against a common, but problematic, approach.
content.text: It is advisable to avoid jointly owned intellectual property rights. This is particularly true if the development work/collaboration can result in patentable inventions.

content.verbatim_text: Often a better solution is achieved through agreeing on one party owning all of the intellectual property generated as a result of the collaborative innovation/development and on licensing it to the other party on a free-of-charge perpetual basis and with sufficiently broad license terms.
content.plain_text: A better solution for collaborative development is for one party to own all generated IP, and license it to the other party on a free-of-charge, perpetual, and broadly licensed basis.
content.expert_insight: This provides a clear, actionable alternative to joint ownership, ensuring one party has clear control while the other retains necessary usage rights, streamlining future exploitation.
content.conditions: Applies to intellectual property generated as a result of collaborative innovation/development.
content.justification: The text presents this as 'Often a better solution' to avoiding joint ownership.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can either own the IP and license it out, or receive a broad license from the supplier, avoiding joint ownership issues.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier can either own the IP and license it out, or receive a broad license from Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: This is a recommended alternative to joint ownership.
content.text: Often a better solution is achieved through agreeing on one party owning all of the intellectual property generated as a result of the collaborative innovation/development and on licensing it to the other party on a free-of-charge perpetual basis and with sufficiently broad license terms.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s own existing intellectual property rights should never be transferred, assigned or sold in an ordinary procurement contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's existing intellectual property rights should never be transferred, assigned, or sold in an ordinary procurement contract.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental principle for protecting Zebracorp's core assets. Transferring existing IP in a standard procurement context would be a significant strategic error, eroding competitive advantage.
content.conditions: Applies to Zebracorp's own existing intellectual property rights in ordinary procurement contracts.
content.justification: The text uses 'should never be transferred,' indicating an absolute prohibition.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains full ownership and control of its existing IPRs.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier cannot acquire Zebracorp's existing IPRs in ordinary procurement.
content.source_insight: This is a core protective rule for Zebracorp's IP.
content.text: Zebracorp’s own existing intellectual property rights should never be transferred, assigned or sold in an ordinary procurement contract.

content.verbatim_text: At most we can consider granting limited licenses to use certain specified Zebracorp IPR for the purpose of performing the supplier/subcontractor’s obligations towards Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may consider granting only limited licenses to use specified Zebracorp IPR, solely for the purpose of enabling the supplier/subcontractor to fulfill their obligations to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This sets a strict boundary for sharing Zebracorp's IP, ensuring any access granted to suppliers is narrowly tailored to operational necessity and does not compromise Zebracorp's proprietary position.
content.conditions: Applies when considering granting licenses to suppliers for Zebracorp IPR.
content.justification: The text uses 'At most we can consider,' indicating a highly restricted allowance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains control over its IPRs, granting only necessary, limited access.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier receives limited access to Zebracorp IPR, strictly for performing obligations.
content.source_insight: This defines the maximum permissible license for Zebracorp's own IP.
content.text: At most we can consider granting limited licenses to use certain specified Zebracorp IPR for the purpose of performing the supplier/subcontractor’s obligations towards Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: In such event it is worthwhile specifying that the license is limited, non-exclusive, revocable, and granted solely for such purpose, and for no other purpose whatsoever.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp grants a limited license to its IPR, it is worthwhile specifying that the license is limited, non-exclusive, revocable, and granted solely for the stated purpose.
content.expert_insight: These specific terms (limited, non-exclusive, revocable, purpose-specific) are crucial for safeguarding Zebracorp's IP, preventing unintended broad usage or permanent rights for the supplier.
content.conditions: Applies when granting limited licenses to use specified Zebracorp IPR.
content.justification: The text uses 'it is worthwhile specifying' and lists critical protective terms.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains maximum control and flexibility over its IPRs, limiting supplier's rights.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's license to Zebracorp IPR is strictly limited in scope and duration.
content.source_insight: This provides the specific protective terms for licenses to Zebracorp's own IP.
content.text: In such event it is worthwhile specifying that the license is limited, non-exclusive, revocable, and granted solely for such purpose, and for no other purpose whatsoever.

content.verbatim_text: Where needed, please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team to assist with the correct wording.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp personnel should consult with the Legal & Compliance team for assistance with correct wording when granting licenses to Zebracorp IPR.
content.expert_insight: Legal consultation is essential for drafting precise and legally sound IP clauses, especially when licensing Zebracorp's own IP, to avoid ambiguities that could lead to significant legal and commercial risks.
content.conditions: Applies when drafting wording for licenses to Zebracorp IPR.
content.justification: The text uses 'please consult,' indicating a mandatory internal process for legal accuracy.
content.implication_company: Ensures legal accuracy and protection of Zebracorp's IPRs.
content.implication_supplier: Indirectly, as Zebracorp's legal accuracy will affect contract terms.
content.source_insight: This is a procedural guideline for internal consultation.
content.text: Where needed, please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team to assist with the correct wording.

content.verbatim_text: Any other license to Zebracorp IPR should be subject to a separate written license agreement.
content.plain_text: Any license to Zebracorp IPR beyond limited operational use should be documented in a separate written license agreement.
content.expert_insight: This ensures that any significant licensing of Zebracorp's IP is handled with the appropriate formality and detailed terms, separate from standard procurement, reflecting its strategic importance.
content.conditions: Applies to any license to Zebracorp IPR beyond limited operational use.
content.justification: The text uses 'should be subject to a separate written license agreement,' indicating a formal requirement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp ensures proper legal framework for significant IP licensing.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier must enter into a separate agreement for broader licenses to Zebracorp IPR.
content.source_insight: This is a formal requirement for licensing Zebracorp's IP.
content.text: Any other license to Zebracorp IPR should be subject to a separate written license agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Care should be taken with Feedback and Residuals clauses, as the suppliers quite often expect to get a full license (including patents) in particular to the Feedback (see the Confidentiality Clause in this document).
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should exercise care with Feedback and Residuals clauses, as suppliers often expect broad licenses (including patents) for feedback.
content.expert_insight: Feedback and Residuals clauses can inadvertently grant broad IP rights to suppliers, potentially compromising Zebracorp's future innovations. Careful drafting is essential to protect Zebracorp's IP.
content.conditions: Applies when dealing with Feedback and Residuals clauses.
content.justification: The text uses 'Care should be taken' and explains the supplier's common expectation.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp protects its future innovations and IPRs from being inadvertently licensed to suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's expectations for broad licenses to feedback may be challenged.
content.source_insight: This highlights a specific area of risk in IP clauses.
content.text: Care should be taken with Feedback and Residuals clauses, as the suppliers quite often expect to get a full license (including patents) in particular to the Feedback (see the Confidentiality Clause in this document).

content.verbatim_text: In most contracts it is sufficient to say that each party retains its and its licensors IPRs and that there is no transfer of any IPRs from one party to the other.
content.plain_text: In most contracts, Zebracorp's preferred position is that each party retains its own and its licensors' IPRs, with no transfer of IPRs between parties.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a baseline for standard contracts where IP is not the primary deliverable, simplifying negotiations by maintaining the status quo of IP ownership.
content.conditions: Applies to 'most contracts' where IPR is not the primary focus.
content.justification: The text states 'it is sufficient to say,' indicating a standard, acceptable position.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains its IPRs and avoids acquiring supplier's IPRs.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier retains its IPRs and avoids acquiring Zebracorp's IPRs.
content.source_insight: This is Zebracorp's general preferred position for non-development contracts.
content.text: In most contracts it is sufficient to say that each party retains its and its licensors IPRs and that there is no transfer of any IPRs from one party to the other.

content.verbatim_text: The above does not apply to any development agreements where it is in fact mandatory to agree specifically which party will become the owner of the results of the development and how pre-existing IPR will be treated.
content.plain_text: The general rule of retaining IPRs does not apply to development agreements, where it is mandatory to specifically agree on ownership of development results and treatment of pre-existing IPR.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the critical distinction for development agreements, where IP creation is central. Explicitly defining ownership and treatment of pre-existing IP is non-negotiable to avoid significant future disputes.
content.conditions: Applies to development agreements.
content.justification: The text uses 'it is in fact mandatory to agree specifically,' indicating an absolute requirement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure specific IPR ownership and treatment clauses in development agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier must negotiate specific IPR ownership and treatment in development agreements.
content.source_insight: This is a critical exception to the general rule.
content.text: The above does not apply to any development agreements where it is in fact mandatory to agree specifically which party will become the owner of the results of the development and how pre-existing IPR will be treated.

content.verbatim_text: Any material deviations and variations to the terms to the IPR provisions of the respective Zebracorp development agreements templates are recommended to be reviewed by Legal & Compliance.
content.plain_text: Any material deviations or variations to the IPR provisions in Zebracorp's development agreement templates are recommended for review by Legal & Compliance.
content.expert_insight: Given the high stakes of IP in development agreements, any significant changes to standard templates must undergo legal review to mitigate risks and ensure compliance with Zebracorp's strategic IP objectives.
content.conditions: Applies to material deviations and variations to IPR provisions in Zebracorp development agreement templates.
content.justification: The text uses 'recommended to be reviewed by Legal & Compliance' for 'material deviations' in a critical area.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp ensures legal scrutiny for high-risk IPR clause modifications.
content.implication_supplier: Indirectly, as Zebracorp's internal review process will affect negotiation flexibility.
content.source_insight: This is a procedural guideline for legal review of critical IP clauses.
content.text: Any material deviations and variations to the terms to the IPR provisions of the respective Zebracorp development agreements templates are recommended to be reviewed by Legal & Compliance.

content.verbatim_text: However, in development agreements or any such agreements where the supplier is contracted to deliver certain work results to Zebracorp (in e.g. consultancy agreements) we should expressly agree on the ownership of the results of the development or other work.
content.plain_text: In development or consultancy agreements where a supplier delivers work results, Zebracorp must explicitly agree on the ownership of those results.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a critical distinction: while general contracts might be silent on IPR, development agreements require explicit ownership clauses to protect Zebracorp's investment and future use of custom-developed assets.
content.justification: This is a direct instruction on a mandatory action for specific contract types.
content.implication_company: Failure to explicitly agree on ownership could result in the supplier retaining rights to work Zebracorp paid for, limiting Zebracorp's ability to use or exploit it.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will need to be prepared to negotiate IPR ownership in development agreements, as Zebracorp will not remain silent on this point.
content.source_insight: The text implies a default legal position where the creator owns the IPR if not explicitly agreed otherwise, making this instruction crucial.
content.text: However, in development agreements or any such agreements where the supplier is contracted to deliver certain work results to Zebracorp (in e.g. consultancy agreements) we should expressly agree on the ownership of the results of the development or other work.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever Zebracorp intends to order professional services such as in e.g. design/development work, consulting work, integration work or customizations, it is important to agree on the ownership of the development/service results.
content.plain_text: For professional services like design, development, consulting, integration, or customizations, Zebracorp must agree on the ownership of the resulting work.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces the previous instruction, broadening its scope to all professional services that generate new work results. It's a foundational principle for Zebracorp's procurement strategy in these areas.
content.justification: This is a clear statement of importance and a required action for specific service types.
content.implication_company: Ensuring ownership of service results is vital for Zebracorp to fully leverage its investments in professional services and maintain control over its intellectual assets.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers providing these types of services should expect IPR ownership to be a key negotiation point.
content.source_insight: The text immediately follows with Zebracorp's default template position, indicating this is a core policy.
content.text: Whenever Zebracorp intends to order professional services such as in e.g. design/development work, consulting work, integration work or customizations, it is important to agree on the ownership of the development/service results.

content.verbatim_text: In some cases it makes commercial sense to allow the supplier/subcontractor to sell the service results such as in e.g. a generic market research report to its other customers as well. Such right for the supplier should obviously specifically exclude any Zebracorp proprietary or confidential items.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may allow suppliers to sell generic service results (e.g., market research reports) to other customers, but this must explicitly exclude any Zebracorp proprietary or confidential information.
content.expert_insight: This offers a pragmatic negotiation tactic, allowing flexibility for the supplier while safeguarding Zebracorp's core assets. It recognizes that not all 'results of services' are equally strategic to Zebracorp.
content.justification: This provides strategic advice on when and how to concede certain rights to a supplier, with a crucial safeguard.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can achieve cost savings or better terms by allowing suppliers to monetize generic work, provided its sensitive information is protected.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can gain additional revenue streams from generic work, making Zebracorp's projects more attractive, but must respect Zebracorp's proprietary and confidential information.
content.source_insight: The 'obviously' indicates this is a non-negotiable safeguard within the concession.
content.text: In some cases it makes commercial sense to allow the supplier/subcontractor to sell the service results such as in e.g. a generic market research report to its other customers as well. Such right for the supplier should obviously specifically exclude any Zebracorp proprietary or confidential items.

content.verbatim_text: Also, the supplier is likely to assert ownership in any modifications or derivative works of its own products even if Zebracorp has ordered and paid for such modification. This can be addressed by adding the following type of provision: “The Parties agree that any [Intellectual Property Rights] in and to the [Service Results] shall vest in and become the sole and exclusive property of the [Buyer], save for any derivative work or other modification of the [Supplier Product] which will be owned by the [Supplier], unless otherwise expressly agreed between the Parties.”
content.plain_text: Suppliers often claim ownership of modifications or derivative works of their own products, even if Zebracorp paid for them. This can be resolved by a clause stating Zebracorp owns service results, except for derivative works or modifications of supplier products, which the supplier retains unless otherwise agreed.
content.expert_insight: This anticipates a common supplier negotiation point and provides a specific contractual solution. It balances Zebracorp's desire for ownership with the supplier's interest in its core product IP.
content.justification: It identifies a common supplier stance and offers a specific contractual provision to address it.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can secure ownership of the service results while acknowledging the supplier's rights to its underlying product, facilitating agreement.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can protect their core product IP while still engaging in development work for Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The example clause provided is a direct implementation of the tactic.
content.text: Also, the supplier is likely to assert ownership in any modifications or derivative works of its own products even if Zebracorp has ordered and paid for such modification. This can be addressed by adding the following type of provision: “The Parties agree that any [Intellectual Property Rights] in and to the [Service Results] shall vest in and become the sole and exclusive property of the [Buyer], save for any derivative work or other modification of the [Supplier Product] which will be owned by the [Supplier], unless otherwise expressly agreed between the Parties.”

content.verbatim_text: It is recommend to speak to member of the product line or customer team to understand the individual needs of Zebracorp for each particular case.
content.plain_text: It is recommended to consult with the product line or customer team to understand Zebracorp's specific needs for each case.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the importance of internal alignment and understanding the business context before finalizing IPR terms. A 'one-size-fits-all' approach is insufficient for IPR.
content.justification: This is an internal process instruction for gathering necessary information.
content.implication_company: Ensures IPR agreements align with Zebracorp's strategic and commercial objectives for the specific product or service.
content.implication_supplier: Indirectly, this means Zebracorp's IPR position will be well-informed and tailored to its business needs, potentially leading to more focused negotiations.
content.source_insight: This instruction appears after discussing various IPR ownership scenarios, indicating the need for case-by-case assessment.
content.text: It is recommend to speak to member of the product line or customer team to understand the individual needs of Zebracorp for each particular case.

content.verbatim_text: In those global procurement contracts where the supplier refuses to grant us ownership by default, we should often seek to secure a provision where we agree that Zebracorp or its end customer specific customizations are always owned by Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: For global procurement contracts where suppliers resist default ownership transfer, Zebracorp should aim for a provision ensuring Zebracorp or its end-customer specific customizations are always owned by Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This outlines a key compromise tactic for challenging negotiations, prioritizing ownership of Zebracorp-specific elements even if full ownership of all deliverables isn't achievable.
content.justification: This describes a specific negotiation strategy for a common scenario (supplier refusal of default ownership).
content.implication_company: Zebracorp secures ownership of its unique, strategic customizations, protecting its competitive advantage even in complex global deals.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may find this a more palatable compromise than full ownership transfer, as it allows them to retain rights to their generic product while accommodating Zebracorp's specific needs.
content.source_insight: The text provides an example of such 'compromise language' immediately after this instruction.
content.text: In those global procurement contracts where the supplier refuses to grant us ownership by default, we should often seek to secure a provision where we agree that Zebracorp or its end customer specific customizations are always owned by Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Note that in cases where we do agree that the supplier/subcontractor retains ownership of the result of the services, it is imperative to agree on our license i.e. right to use those service results that we do not own.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp agrees that the supplier retains ownership of service results, it is crucial to secure a license for Zebracorp to use those results.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental safeguard. If Zebracorp doesn't own the IP, it must at least have a robust license to ensure it can still utilize the deliverables it paid for. This prevents future disputes or unexpected costs.
content.justification: This is a critical instruction for mitigating risk when Zebracorp does not obtain full ownership.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp can still use the service results even if it doesn't own the underlying IP, preventing project paralysis or additional licensing fees.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be prepared to grant appropriate licenses when retaining ownership, as Zebracorp will require the right to use the deliverables.
content.source_insight: The text provides example language for such a license, emphasizing its importance.
content.text: Note that in cases where we do agree that the supplier/subcontractor retains ownership of the result of the services, it is imperative to agree on our license i.e. right to use those service results that we do not own.

content.verbatim_text: Unsurprisingly, you may find the suppliers keen to shift the discussion of the IPR ownership to the Statement of Work by proposing to replace the IPR sections of the agreement with a note saying that the IPR ownership will be agreed in a Statement of Work on a case-by-case basis. While this sounds like an easy option, and while it is certainly true that it is difficult to agree on the ownership of service or development work that we are yet to request, it is nevertheless important to have a fall-back provision that determines the ownership of the IPR in the event the IPR ownership provision is omitted in the Statement of Work.
content.plain_text: Suppliers often try to defer IPR ownership discussions to the Statement of Work (SOW). While this seems convenient, Zebracorp must include a fallback provision in the main agreement to determine IPR ownership if it's omitted from the SOW.
content.expert_insight: This identifies a common supplier tactic and provides a counter-tactic. It acknowledges the practical difficulties of upfront SOW-level IPR agreement but stresses the necessity of a safety net to avoid legal defaults.
content.justification: This describes a common supplier negotiation strategy and provides Zebracorp with a counter-strategy to protect its interests.
content.implication_company: Prevents Zebracorp from being caught without an IPR ownership agreement, which could lead to the supplier retaining rights by default.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' attempts to defer IPR discussions will be met with a requirement for a fallback provision in the main agreement.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states 'Most likely time and resource constraints will not allow us to start discussion on IPR ownership when entering into a Statement of Work,' reinforcing the need for a fallback.
content.text: Unsurprisingly, you may find the suppliers keen to shift the discussion of the IPR ownership to the Statement of Work by proposing to replace the IPR sections of the agreement with a note saying that the IPR ownership will be agreed in a Statement of Work on a case-by-case basis. While this sounds like an easy option, and while it is certainly true that it is difficult to agree on the ownership of service or development work that we are yet to request, it is nevertheless important to have a fall-back provision that determines the ownership of the IPR in the event the IPR ownership provision is omitted in the Statement of Work.

content.verbatim_text: A compromise can often be found by laying out the basic rules on the division of IPRs between the supplier and Zebracorp substantially in line with the above mentioned guidelines and by leaving the option to define the ownership in more detail in the Statement of Work or, if necessary, even to deviate from these ground rules in the Statement of Work.
content.plain_text: A compromise for IPR ownership can involve establishing basic IPR division rules in the main agreement, allowing for more detailed definition or even deviation in the Statement of Work.
content.expert_insight: This offers a flexible and practical negotiation approach, combining the need for a fallback with the reality of SOW-specific details. It provides a structured way to manage IPR in complex engagements.
content.justification: This outlines a specific compromise strategy for IPR ownership discussions.
content.implication_company: Provides a clear framework for IPR, reducing negotiation friction while maintaining flexibility for specific projects.
content.implication_supplier: Offers a structured approach that balances the supplier's desire for SOW-level detail with Zebracorp's need for overarching protection.
content.source_insight: This directly follows the discussion about suppliers trying to shift IPR to the SOW, presenting a solution.
content.text: A compromise can often be found by laying out the basic rules on the division of IPRs between the supplier and Zebracorp substantially in line with the above mentioned guidelines and by leaving the option to define the ownership in more detail in the Statement of Work or, if necessary, even to deviate from these ground rules in the Statement of Work.

content.verbatim_text: The phrase “…prior to and in no relation to…” in the above sentence can often be negotiated to “…prior to or in no relation to…”
content.plain_text: The phrase 'prior to and in no relation to' regarding supplier's pre-existing IPR can often be negotiated to 'prior to or in no relation to'.
content.expert_insight: This is a very specific, tactical negotiation point. Changing 'and' to 'or' significantly broadens the scope of what is considered supplier pre-existing IPR, potentially benefiting the supplier by making it easier to prove their prior ownership.
content.justification: This provides a specific linguistic negotiation point with a clear impact.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be aware of this subtle but significant change and its implications for defining supplier pre-existing IPR.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can use this as a negotiation point to more easily protect their pre-existing IPR.
content.source_insight: This is presented as a direct negotiation tip for a specific clause.
content.text: The phrase “…prior to and in no relation to…” in the above sentence can often be negotiated to “…prior to or in no relation to…”

content.verbatim_text: However, we must have a license to use these pre-existing IPRs. In the absence of such license the supplier could potentially later claim royalties or license fees for our use of the results of the services.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must obtain a license to use any supplier pre-existing IPR embedded in the service results; otherwise, the supplier could later demand royalties or fees.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical risk mitigation instruction. Even if Zebracorp doesn't own the pre-existing IPR, it must secure usage rights to avoid future financial liabilities or operational restrictions.
content.justification: This is a mandatory requirement to prevent future financial and operational risks.
content.implication_company: Securing this license protects Zebracorp from unexpected costs and ensures uninterrupted use of the deliverables.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers embedding pre-existing IPR into deliverables must be prepared to grant Zebracorp a license for its use.
content.source_insight: The text immediately follows with an example of such a license, underscoring its importance.
content.text: However, we must have a license to use these pre-existing IPRs. In the absence of such license the supplier could potentially later claim royalties or license fees for our use of the results of the services.

content.verbatim_text: The term ‘warrants’ at the end of the above clause can be changed to less stringent word such as ‘shall ensure’ or this warranty can be negotiated away be entirely removing the last bit that starts with: “….and the [Supplier] warrants…”
content.plain_text: The term 'warrants' in the license clause can be negotiated to a less stringent 'shall ensure' or removed entirely.
content.expert_insight: This offers specific negotiation leverage on the strength of supplier commitments, allowing Zebracorp to adjust the risk profile based on the specific context and supplier relationship.
content.justification: This provides specific negotiation points for modifying contractual language.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can reduce the supplier's liability or streamline the clause if the full strength of a 'warrants' clause is not deemed necessary.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can seek to reduce their liability by negotiating weaker warranty language or removing it altogether.
content.source_insight: This is presented as a direct negotiation tip for a specific clause.
content.text: The term ‘warrants’ at the end of the above clause can be changed to less stringent word such as ‘shall ensure’ or this warranty can be negotiated away be entirely removing the last bit that starts with: “….and the [Supplier] warrants…”

content.verbatim_text: The license does not need to be unlimited but it can in fact be specifically labelled as a limited license. Also the license is not required to be exclusive but we can in most cases readily consent to the above license being ‘non-exclusive’ i.e. allow the supplier to license the same pre-existing IPRs to its other customers as well.
content.plain_text: The license for pre-existing IPR doesn't have to be unlimited or exclusive; Zebracorp can agree to a limited or non-exclusive license, allowing the supplier to license the same IPR to other customers.
content.expert_insight: This provides flexibility in negotiation, allowing Zebracorp to concede on exclusivity or scope if it doesn't need full rights, potentially gaining other concessions from the supplier.
content.justification: This offers specific negotiation points regarding the scope and exclusivity of licenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this flexibility to achieve a more balanced agreement, potentially reducing costs or improving other terms.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can retain broader rights to their pre-existing IPR, making the deal more commercially attractive for them.
content.source_insight: This directly follows the discussion of the standard license clause, offering ways to modify it.
content.text: The license does not need to be unlimited but it can in fact be specifically labelled as a limited license. Also the license is not required to be exclusive but we can in most cases readily consent to the above license being ‘non-exclusive’ i.e. allow the supplier to license the same pre-existing IPRs to its other customers as well.

content.verbatim_text: Unless Zebracorp obtains full ownership to any and all IPRs in the deliverables, no matter when created, it is advisable to insert a clause into the [development] agreement that supplier has no right to include any pre-existing IPR into the deliverables/Zebracorp product unless otherwise expressly agreed in writing. This is to avoid any cases where the supplier might later assert IP ownership claim into certain part of Zebracorp product due to fact that Zebracorp product contains supplier pre-existing IPR.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp doesn't get full ownership of all IPR in deliverables, it's advisable to include a clause preventing the supplier from embedding pre-existing IPR into Zebracorp products unless explicitly agreed in writing. This prevents future IP claims by the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This is a proactive risk management tactic. It prevents 'IP creep' where supplier pre-existing IP might inadvertently become part of Zebracorp's core product, leading to future ownership disputes or licensing demands.
content.justification: This is a strategic recommendation to prevent future IP ownership disputes and protect Zebracorp's products.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from unintended co-ownership or licensing obligations for its own products.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be mindful of this restriction and seek explicit agreement if they intend to embed their pre-existing IPR.
content.source_insight: The justification for this tactic is explicitly stated: 'to avoid any cases where the supplier might later assert IP ownership claim'.
content.text: Unless Zebracorp obtains full ownership to any and all IPRs in the deliverables, no matter when created, it is advisable to insert a clause into the [development] agreement that supplier has no right to include any pre-existing IPR into the deliverables/Zebracorp product unless otherwise expressly agreed in writing. This is to avoid any cases where the supplier might later assert IP ownership claim into certain part of Zebracorp product due to fact that Zebracorp product contains supplier pre-existing IPR.

content.verbatim_text: Whatever the adaptation is, it may be important to specifically mention that IPRs to such adaptation remain with Zebracorp. This can be controversial as the suppliers will – understandably – be concerned with retaining the own intellectual property rights in their product. This potential bone of contention can often be resolved by defining the Zebracorp adaptation in sufficient detail and by adding clarifying language such as: “the foregoing will not be construed to transfer or assign any ownership or title to any intellectual property rights of the supplier in the underlying product but the supplier and its licensors will retain all such rights despite any adaptations made by or for [ZEBRACORP]“, or similar wording to safeguard supplier’s IP ownership in the underlying product.
content.plain_text: It's important to specify that IPRs for Zebracorp's adaptations remain with Zebracorp. This can be contentious with suppliers, but can be resolved by clearly defining the adaptation and adding language that safeguards the supplier's ownership of the underlying product.
content.expert_insight: This addresses a common conflict point in adaptation scenarios. It provides a clear strategy: assert ownership of the adaptation while reassuring the supplier that their core product IP is protected, facilitating agreement.
content.justification: This identifies a potential conflict and provides a specific negotiation strategy and contractual language to resolve it.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp secures ownership of its unique adaptations, protecting its investment and customization efforts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are reassured that their core product IP is not being transferred, making them more amenable to Zebracorp owning the adaptations.
content.source_insight: The text provides an example of 'clarifying language' to implement this tactic.
content.text: Whatever the adaptation is, it may be important to specifically mention that IPRs to such adaptation remain with Zebracorp. This can be controversial as the suppliers will – understandably – be concerned with retaining the own intellectual property rights in their product. This potential bone of contention can often be resolved by defining the Zebracorp adaptation in sufficient detail and by adding clarifying language such as: “the foregoing will not be construed to transfer or assign any ownership or title to any intellectual property rights of the supplier in the underlying product but the supplier and its licensors will retain all such rights despite any adaptations made by or for [ZEBRACORP]“, or similar wording to safeguard supplier’s IP ownership in the underlying product.

content.verbatim_text: Note that if Zebracorp provides any specifications or copyrighted material to the supplier, it is important to also mention that Zebracorp’s ownership rights extend to any modifications or further development of any of those Zebracorp materials and information. Should we fail to assert our rights also to these modifications or derivative works, there is a risk that the supplier/subcontractor might modify our copyrighted materials and subsequently claim copyright to the “new” modified work.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp provides copyrighted materials to a supplier, it's crucial to state that Zebracorp's ownership extends to any modifications or derivative works of those materials. Failing to do so risks the supplier claiming copyright to the modified work.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical defensive tactic. It prevents suppliers from 'hijacking' Zebracorp's IP by making minor modifications and then claiming ownership of the derivative work, which is a common IP risk.
content.justification: This is a crucial instruction to prevent the loss of IP rights and mitigate a specific risk.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp's existing IP from being claimed by suppliers through modification.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must acknowledge Zebracorp's ownership of derivative works based on Zebracorp's provided materials.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states the risk: 'there is a risk that the supplier/subcontractor might modify our copyrighted materials and subsequently claim copyright to the “new” modified work'.
content.text: Note that if Zebracorp provides any specifications or copyrighted material to the supplier, it is important to also mention that Zebracorp’s ownership rights extend to any modifications or further development of any of those Zebracorp materials and information. Should we fail to assert our rights also to these modifications or derivative works, there is a risk that the supplier/subcontractor might modify our copyrighted materials and subsequently claim copyright to the “new” modified work.

content.verbatim_text: Foreground IPRs can be owned by either Zebracorp or the developer depending on the requirements of Zebracorp; this means that we should consider if we can allow the developer to sell the products to parties other than Zebracorp . The ownership should be checked with the respective product owner (product line/product management).
content.plain_text: Ownership of Foreground IPRs (newly created IP) can go to Zebracorp or the developer, depending on Zebracorp's needs. Zebracorp should consider if the developer can sell the products to others, and this decision must be confirmed with the product owner.
content.expert_insight: This outlines a key decision point for Foreground IPR, emphasizing that the default isn't always Zebracorp ownership and requiring internal consultation to align with business strategy.
content.justification: This provides a decision-making framework and an internal consultation instruction for Foreground IPR.
content.implication_company: Ensures IPR ownership aligns with Zebracorp's commercial strategy and product roadmap, preventing unintended restrictions or missed opportunities.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may have opportunities to retain or share ownership of Foreground IPR, depending on Zebracorp's specific needs.
content.source_insight: The instruction to 'check with the respective product owner' highlights the internal process.
content.text: Foreground IPRs can be owned by either Zebracorp or the developer depending on the requirements of Zebracorp; this means that we should consider if we can allow the developer to sell the products to parties other than Zebracorp . The ownership should be checked with the respective product owner (product line/product management).

content.verbatim_text: Also in cases where Zebracorp pays for the development work, Zebracorp should as a baseline acquire full unrestricted ownership.
content.plain_text: When Zebracorp pays for development work, it should, as a baseline, acquire full unrestricted ownership of the resulting IP.
content.expert_insight: This establishes Zebracorp's default and preferred position for Foreground IPR when it funds the development, setting a strong starting point for negotiations.
content.justification: This states Zebracorp's baseline position for IPR ownership in development work.
content.implication_company: Secures Zebracorp's investment and ensures maximum flexibility in exploiting the developed IP.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to seek full ownership when it funds development, requiring them to justify any deviation.
content.source_insight: This is presented as a 'baseline' position, indicating it's the starting point for negotiation.
content.text: Also in cases where Zebracorp pays for the development work, Zebracorp should as a baseline acquire full unrestricted ownership.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever we agree that Zebracorp does not become the owner of the foreground IPR, we should agree on a broad license (i.e. the right to use) that Zebracorp obtains into such foreground IPR. Such licenses can often be exclusive which mean that only Zebracorp will have the right to use foreground works and the developer is prevented from licensing the foreground IPR to its other customers.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp doesn't own Foreground IPR, it must secure a broad license to use it. This license can often be exclusive, preventing the developer from licensing it to other customers.
content.expert_insight: This provides a critical fallback strategy: if ownership isn't possible, secure the strongest possible license, ideally exclusive, to protect Zebracorp's investment and competitive position.
content.justification: This is an instruction on securing necessary rights when full ownership is not achieved, including a specific type of license to aim for.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp can still fully utilize the developed IP, even without ownership, and potentially maintain exclusivity.
content.implication_supplier: Developers must be prepared to grant broad, potentially exclusive, licenses if Zebracorp does not take ownership of Foreground IPR.
content.source_insight: The text clarifies 'broad license' by giving 'exclusive' as an example, showing the preferred scope.
content.text: Whenever we agree that Zebracorp does not become the owner of the foreground IPR, we should agree on a broad license (i.e. the right to use) that Zebracorp obtains into such foreground IPR. Such licenses can often be exclusive which mean that only Zebracorp will have the right to use foreground works and the developer is prevented from licensing the foreground IPR to its other customers.

content.verbatim_text: In any event it is important to make sure that license is sufficiently broad/comprehensive to give us the rights we need to exploit the results of development in the manner that we had contemplated.
content.plain_text: It is crucial to ensure any license obtained is broad and comprehensive enough for Zebracorp to exploit the development results as intended.
content.expert_insight: This is a general but vital instruction, emphasizing that the *scope* of the license is paramount, not just its existence. It requires foresight into Zebracorp's future use cases.
content.justification: This is a general instruction on the necessary quality and scope of any license obtained.
content.implication_company: Prevents future restrictions on Zebracorp's ability to use or adapt the developed IP, ensuring its commercial value.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must understand Zebracorp's intended use of the IP to tailor license terms appropriately.
content.source_insight: This instruction acts as a guiding principle for all license negotiations.
content.text: In any event it is important to make sure that license is sufficiently broad/comprehensive to give us the rights we need to exploit the results of development in the manner that we had contemplated.

content.verbatim_text: In case the development work includes the implementation of any Zebracorp proprietary items, Zebracorp should retain IPR ownership to such proprietary items as default, without any license to the supplier. These proprietary items are typically very Zebracorp specific requirements, which we cannot permit or allow the supplier to sell (once implemented) to any parties other than Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: If development work involves Zebracorp's proprietary items, Zebracorp should retain IPR ownership by default, without granting a license to the supplier. These are typically Zebracorp-specific requirements that cannot be sold to others.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical safeguard for Zebracorp's core, unique IP. It prevents suppliers from leveraging Zebracorp's proprietary elements for other clients, protecting Zebracorp's competitive edge.
content.justification: This is a mandatory instruction to protect Zebracorp's core proprietary IP.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp's unique competitive assets from being commercialized by suppliers for other parties.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must acknowledge that Zebracorp's proprietary items remain Zebracorp's exclusive property and cannot be reused or sold.
content.source_insight: The justification for this instruction is explicitly provided, emphasizing the unique and non-transferable nature of these items.
content.text: In case the development work includes the implementation of any Zebracorp proprietary items, Zebracorp should retain IPR ownership to such proprietary items as default, without any license to the supplier. These proprietary items are typically very Zebracorp specific requirements, which we cannot permit or allow the supplier to sell (once implemented) to any parties other than Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: It is advisable to avoid jointly owned intellectual property rights. This is particularly true if the development work/collaboration can result in patentable inventions.
content.plain_text: It is advisable to avoid jointly owned intellectual property rights, especially if the collaboration could lead to patentable inventions.
content.expert_insight: This is a strong strategic recommendation against joint ownership, highlighting the practical difficulties and complexities it introduces, particularly for high-value IP like patents.
content.justification: This provides strategic advice to avoid a specific type of IPR ownership due to inherent complexities and risks.
content.implication_company: Avoiding joint ownership streamlines decision-making and exploitation of IP, preventing potential deadlocks or disputes.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that Zebracorp will likely resist joint ownership proposals.
content.source_insight: The text details the difficulties of joint ownership (e.g., joint decisions, patent complications) immediately before this advice.
content.text: It is advisable to avoid jointly owned intellectual property rights. This is particularly true if the development work/collaboration can result in patentable inventions.

content.verbatim_text: Often a better solution is achieved through agreeing on one party owning all of the intellectual property generated as a result of the collaborative innovation/development and on licensing it to the other party on a free-of-charge perpetual basis and with sufficiently broad license terms. As an alternative the portfolio of intellectual property created may be divided out between the parties, based on the vested interests of each party.
content.plain_text: A better alternative to joint ownership is for one party to own all IP from collaboration and license it broadly and perpetually to the other for free. Another option is to divide the IP portfolio based on each party's interests.
content.expert_insight: These are practical, alternative tactics to joint ownership, offering structured ways to share benefits without the complexities of co-ownership. They provide clear negotiation pathways.
content.justification: These are specific alternative strategies to avoid joint ownership while still accommodating both parties' interests.
content.implication_company: Provides clear strategies for managing IP in collaborative efforts without the pitfalls of joint ownership.
content.implication_supplier: Offers structured alternatives to joint ownership, which suppliers can propose or accept.
content.source_insight: These solutions are presented directly after the advice to avoid joint ownership.
content.text: Often a better solution is achieved through agreeing on one party owning all of the intellectual property generated as a result of the collaborative innovation/development and on licensing it to the other party on a free-of-charge perpetual basis and with sufficiently broad license terms. As an alternative the portfolio of intellectual property created may be divided out between the parties, based on the vested interests of each party.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s own existing intellectual property rights should never be transferred, assigned or sold in an ordinary procurement contract. At most we can consider granting limited licenses to use certain specified Zebracorp IPR for the purpose of performing the supplier/subcontractor’s obligations towards Zebracorp. In such event it is worthwhile specifying that the license is limited, non-exclusive, revocable, and granted solely for such purpose, and for no other purpose whatsoever.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's existing IPR should never be transferred, assigned, or sold in standard procurement contracts. At most, Zebracorp can grant limited, non-exclusive, revocable licenses for suppliers to use specific IPR solely for fulfilling their obligations to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental, non-negotiable instruction for protecting Zebracorp's core IP. It sets strict boundaries for any concessions, emphasizing control and limited scope.
content.justification: This is a critical instruction on how to protect Zebracorp's existing IPR, including specific limitations for any granted licenses.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp's foundational IP remains secure and under its control, preventing inadvertent loss or dilution.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should understand that Zebracorp's existing IP is not for sale or broad licensing; any access will be highly restricted.
content.source_insight: The strong language 'should never be transferred' and 'at most we can consider' highlights the strictness of this policy.
content.text: Zebracorp’s own existing intellectual property rights should never be transferred, assigned or sold in an ordinary procurement contract. At most we can consider granting limited licenses to use certain specified Zebracorp IPR for the purpose of performing the supplier/subcontractor’s obligations towards Zebracorp. In such event it is worthwhile specifying that the license is limited, non-exclusive, revocable, and granted solely for such purpose, and for no other purpose whatsoever.

content.verbatim_text: Care should be taken with Feedback and Residuals clauses, as the suppliers quite often expect to get a full license (including patents) in particular to the Feedback (see the Confidentiality Clause in this document).

content.justification: This highlights a specific area of negotiation where suppliers have common expectations that Zebracorp needs to manage carefully.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must be vigilant to avoid inadvertently granting broad IP rights to suppliers through these clauses.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will likely push for broad rights to feedback and residuals, making this a potential point of contention.

content.text: Care should be taken with Feedback and Residuals clauses, as the suppliers quite often expect to get a full license (including patents) in particular to the Feedback (see the Confidentiality Clause in this document).

content.verbatim_text: The above does not apply to any development agreements where it is in fact mandatory to agree specifically which party will become the owner of the results of the development and how pre-existing IPR will be treated.

content.verbatim_text: Intellectual property rights or IPRs are the rights given to individuals or companies over their inventions or other creations. They usually give the inventor/creator an exclusive right over the use of its invention/creation for a certain period of time.
content.plain_text: Intellectual property rights (IPRs) are exclusive rights granted to individuals or companies for their inventions or creations, typically for a limited time.
content.expert_insight: This foundational definition highlights the core nature of IPRs as exclusive rights, which is crucial for understanding subsequent rules and obligations regarding their ownership and use.

content.text: Intellectual property rights or IPRs are the rights given to individuals or companies over their inventions or other creations. They usually give the inventor/creator an exclusive right over the use of its invention/creation for a certain period of time.

content.verbatim_text: The most common types of intellectual property rights include patents, copyrights and trademarks.
content.plain_text: The most common types of intellectual property rights are patents, copyrights, and trademarks.
content.expert_insight: This provides a high-level overview of the primary categories of IPRs, setting the stage for more detailed discussions on each type.
content.justification: This sentence lists the common types of IPRs.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: The most common types of intellectual property rights include patents, copyrights and trademarks.

content.verbatim_text: Patents are granted by state authorities in various countries to certain inventions that provide a solution to a specific technological problem. In order to be patentable, the invention must meet relevant patentability requirements, such as novelty, usefulness and nonobviousness. The invention is typically a product or a process.
content.plain_text: Patents are state-granted rights for inventions solving technological problems, requiring novelty, usefulness, and nonobviousness. An invention is usually a product or process.
content.expert_insight: This definition outlines the core criteria for patentability, which are critical for assessing whether an invention qualifies for patent protection.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Patents are granted by state authorities in various countries to certain inventions that provide a solution to a specific technological problem. In order to be patentable, the invention must meet relevant patentability requirements, such as novelty, usefulness and nonobviousness. The invention is typically a product or a process.

content.verbatim_text: The exclusive right granted to a patent holder is not the “sole right to use” but the right to prevent others from making, using, selling, or distributing the patented invention without the patent holders’ permission.
content.plain_text: A patent grants the holder the exclusive right to prevent others from making, using, selling, or distributing the patented invention without permission, rather than a sole right to use it.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies a common misconception about patent rights. It's a right to exclude, not necessarily a right to use, which is vital for understanding licensing and infringement.
content.conditions: Applies to any patented invention.
content.justification: This statement defines the scope of the exclusive right granted by a patent.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp, as a patent holder, can prevent others from exploiting its patented inventions. As a user of patented technology, Zebracorp must secure permission.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers holding patents can prevent Zebracorp from using their inventions without a license. Suppliers must respect Zebracorp's patents.
content.text: The exclusive right granted to a patent holder is not the “sole right to use” but the right to prevent others from making, using, selling, or distributing the patented invention without the patent holders’ permission.

content.verbatim_text: Copyright laws give creator of a certain piece of work exclusive rights to it. In order to obtain copyright the work should meet minimal standards of originality.
content.plain_text: Copyright laws provide creators with exclusive rights to their work, provided the work meets minimal originality standards.
content.expert_insight: This defines copyright and its primary condition, originality, which is a lower bar than patentability criteria.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Copyright laws give creator of a certain piece of work exclusive rights to it. In order to obtain copyright the work should meet minimal standards of originality.

content.verbatim_text: Copyright does not cover ideas and information themselves but merely the form or manner in which they are expressed. Accordingly, it is possible for two individuals to have copyright to substantially similar work.
content.plain_text: Copyright protects the expression of ideas and information, not the ideas or information themselves. This means two individuals can independently hold copyright to substantially similar works.
content.expert_insight: This crucial distinction clarifies the scope of copyright protection, explaining why independent creation of similar works is permissible.
content.justification: This explains what copyright does and does not cover, and a consequence of this principle.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Copyright does not cover ideas and information themselves but merely the form or manner in which they are expressed. Accordingly, it is possible for two individuals to have copyright to substantially similar work.

content.verbatim_text: Also, unlike patents and trademarks, copyrights do not generally need to be applied with any state authorities but most jurisdictions recognize copyright in any completed work, without any formal registrations.
content.plain_text: Unlike patents and trademarks, copyrights typically do not require formal registration with state authorities; most jurisdictions automatically recognize copyright in completed works.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the automatic nature of copyright protection, which simplifies its acquisition but can complicate proving ownership or infringement in some cases.
content.conditions: Applies in most jurisdictions.
content.justification: This describes a general characteristic of copyright law regarding registration.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's creative works are automatically copyrighted upon completion, but formal registration might offer additional legal benefits in some jurisdictions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' creative works are also automatically copyrighted, meaning Zebracorp needs to respect these rights even without formal registration.
content.text: Also, unlike patents and trademarks, copyrights do not generally need to be applied with any state authorities but most jurisdictions recognize copyright in any completed work, without any formal registrations.

content.verbatim_text: Trademarks are distinctive names, symbols or designs or combination of all of the above, that identify a company or products and services. Trademarks provide their owners with the legal right to prevent others from using a confusingly similar trademark.
content.plain_text: Trademarks are distinctive identifiers (names, symbols, designs, or combinations) for companies, products, or services, granting owners the right to prevent others from using confusingly similar marks.
content.expert_insight: This definition clearly states what trademarks are and their primary function: brand identification and protection against confusion.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Trademarks are distinctive names, symbols or designs or combination of all of the above, that identify a company or products and services. Trademarks provide their owners with the legal right to prevent others from using a confusingly similar trademark.

content.verbatim_text: However, in development agreements or any such agreements where the supplier is contracted to deliver certain work results to Zebracorp (in e.g. consultancy agreements) we should expressly agree on the ownership of the results of the development or other work.
content.plain_text: In development or consultancy agreements where a supplier delivers work results to Zebracorp, explicit agreement on the ownership of those results is mandatory.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical rule for Zebracorp to proactively secure ownership of work it commissions, preventing future disputes. This is especially important where new IP is created.
content.conditions: Applies to development agreements or agreements where a supplier delivers specific work results to Zebracorp.
content.justification: The text explicitly states 'we should expressly agree' on ownership in these specific contract types.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure IPR ownership is clearly defined in contracts for commissioned work to avoid losing rights to valuable new IP.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers entering development or consultancy agreements with Zebracorp must be prepared to negotiate and agree on IPR ownership of the deliverables.
content.text: However, in development agreements or any such agreements where the supplier is contracted to deliver certain work results to Zebracorp (in e.g. consultancy agreements) we should expressly agree on the ownership of the results of the development or other work.

content.verbatim_text: In the absence of such agreement, the IPRs will generally vest with the party that made the invention or created the work.
content.plain_text: Without an explicit agreement on IPR ownership, the rights will typically belong to the party that created the invention or work.
content.expert_insight: This is a default legal principle that Zebracorp must be aware of. It reinforces the need for explicit agreements, as the default often favors the supplier/creator.
content.conditions: Applies when there is no specific agreement on IPR ownership.
content.justification: This states the default legal outcome for IPR ownership.
content.implication_company: If Zebracorp fails to agree on ownership, the IPRs for commissioned work may default to the supplier, potentially requiring Zebracorp to license its own paid-for work.
content.implication_supplier: If no agreement is made, suppliers will generally retain IPR ownership of the work they create for Zebracorp.
content.text: In the absence of such agreement, the IPRs will generally vest with the party that made the invention or created the work.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever Zebracorp intends to order professional services such as in e.g. design/development work, consulting work, integration work or customizations, it is important to agree on the ownership of the development/service results. Most Zebracorp procurement contract templates transfer the ownership to Zebracorp by default. This is largely because Zebracorp pays for the services and therefore it is reasonable to expect that we also receive unrestricted rights to exploit and make use of those work results that we have paid for.
content.plain_text: When Zebracorp orders professional services like design, development, consulting, integration, or customizations, it's crucial to agree on ownership of the results. Zebracorp's contract templates typically transfer ownership to Zebracorp by default, as it pays for the services and expects unrestricted rights to exploit the paid-for work.
content.expert_insight: This explains Zebracorp's standard position and its rationale, which is a strong starting point for negotiations but also highlights areas where suppliers might push back.
content.justification: This provides context on Zebracorp's approach to IPR ownership in service contracts.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should leverage its default contract templates to secure ownership, but be prepared to justify this position.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware of Zebracorp's default expectation of ownership transfer and be prepared to negotiate if they wish to retain rights.
content.text: Whenever Zebracorp intends to order professional services such as in e.g. design/development work, consulting work, integration work or customizations, it is important to agree on the ownership of the development/service results. Most Zebracorp procurement contract templates transfer the ownership to Zebracorp by default. This is largely because Zebracorp pays for the services and therefore it is reasonable to expect that we also receive unrestricted rights to exploit and make use of those work results that we have paid for.

content.verbatim_text: “All right, title and interest in and to all Intellectual Property Rights in or related to any [Results of Services], shall vest in and become the sole and exclusive property of [ZEBRACORP]. If and to the extent it is impossible as a matter of law to transfer ownership in Intellectual Property Rights to [ZEBRACORP], the [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide and unlimited right to use and exploit in any possible manner (including but not limited to the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the [Results of Services], and warrants with respect to its representatives and any third party engaged to the performance of the [Services], that they will do the same.”
content.plain_text: This example clause states that all IPRs in service results vest solely with Zebracorp. If legal transfer is impossible, the supplier grants Zebracorp an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide, and unlimited right to use and exploit (including modify, copy, sublicense) all IPRs related to the results, and warrants that its representatives and third parties will comply.
content.expert_insight: This is a robust default provision aiming for maximum protection for Zebracorp, either through ownership or an extremely broad license. It serves as a benchmark for negotiation.
content.justification: This is presented as an example of Zebracorp's default provision.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp uses this language to secure comprehensive rights to service results.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will encounter this strong language in Zebracorp's templates and should understand its implications for their IPRs.
content.text: “All right, title and interest in and to all Intellectual Property Rights in or related to any [Results of Services], shall vest in and become the sole and exclusive property of [ZEBRACORP]. If and to the extent it is impossible as a matter of law to transfer ownership in Intellectual Property Rights to [ZEBRACORP], the [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide and unlimited right to use and exploit in any possible manner (including but not limited to the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the [Results of Services], and warrants with respect to its representatives and any third party engaged to the performance of the [Services], that they will do the same.”

content.verbatim_text: This default provision can be modified to reflect the individual needs in each case. In many cases Zebracorp has no need or desire to own IPRs to supplier proprietary products or items. Also in some cases it makes commercial sense to allow the supplier/subcontractor to sell the service results such as in e.g. a generic market research report to its other customers as well. Such right for the supplier should obviously specifically exclude any Zebracorp proprietary or confidential items.
content.plain_text: The default IPR provision can be customized. Zebracorp may not always need to own IPRs for supplier proprietary products, and it can be commercially beneficial to allow suppliers to sell generic service results (e.g., market research reports) to other customers, provided Zebracorp's proprietary or confidential items are excluded.
content.expert_insight: This provides flexibility, acknowledging that a 'one-size-fits-all' approach isn't always optimal. It highlights opportunities for mutually beneficial arrangements.
content.justification: This provides context and advice on modifying the default provision.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can be flexible in negotiations, especially for generic or supplier-proprietary items, but must protect its own confidential information.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can negotiate to retain rights to their proprietary products or generic work results, potentially increasing their commercial value.
content.text: This default provision can be modified to reflect the individual needs in each case. In many cases Zebracorp has no need or desire to own IPRs to supplier proprietary products or items. Also in some cases it makes commercial sense to allow the supplier/subcontractor to sell the service results such as in e.g. a generic market research report to its other customers as well. Such right for the supplier should obviously specifically exclude any Zebracorp proprietary or confidential items.

content.verbatim_text: Also, the supplier is likely to assert ownership in any modifications or derivative works of its own products even if Zebracorp has ordered and paid for such modification. This can be addressed by adding the following type of provision: “The Parties agree that any [Intellectual Property Rights] in and to the [Service Results] shall vest in and become the sole and exclusive property of the [Buyer], save for any derivative work or other modification of the [Supplier Product] which will be owned by the [Supplier], unless otherwise expressly agreed between the Parties.”
content.plain_text: Suppliers often claim ownership of modifications or derivative works of their own products, even if Zebracorp paid for them. This can be resolved by including a provision stating that service results vest with the buyer, except for derivative works or modifications of the supplier's product, which remain with the supplier unless otherwise agreed.
content.expert_insight: This addresses a common point of contention. The suggested clause provides a balanced approach, allowing Zebracorp to own the 'results' while respecting the supplier's underlying product IP.
content.conditions: Applies when suppliers modify or create derivative works of their own products for Zebracorp.
content.justification: This provides a specific contractual solution to a common IPR ownership issue.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be aware of this supplier tendency and use the suggested provision to clarify ownership, especially for modifications to supplier products.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can use this provision to protect their ownership of modifications to their core products while still delivering services to Zebracorp.
content.text: Also, the supplier is likely to assert ownership in any modifications or derivative works of its own products even if Zebracorp has ordered and paid for such modification. This can be addressed by adding the following type of provision: “The Parties agree that any [Intellectual Property Rights] in and to the [Service Results] shall vest in and become the sole and exclusive property of the [Buyer], save for any derivative work or other modification of the [Supplier Product] which will be owned by the [Supplier], unless otherwise expressly agreed between the Parties.”

content.verbatim_text: In software in-licensing agreements, we should often be in able to agree that works or modifications that change the source code of the supplier software will always be owned by the supplier/licensor of the software product.
content.plain_text: In software in-licensing agreements, it's often advisable to agree that works or modifications altering the supplier's software source code will be owned by the supplier/licensor.
content.expert_insight: This is a practical approach in software licensing, as suppliers typically want to maintain control and ownership over their core product's source code, even if modified by a licensee.
content.conditions: Applies to software in-licensing agreements.
content.justification: This is a recommended practice for IPR ownership in a specific type of agreement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should expect to concede ownership of source code modifications to suppliers in in-licensing agreements and ensure it has adequate usage rights.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers in software in-licensing agreements should advocate for retaining ownership of source code modifications to their products.
