content.text: It is recommend to speak to member of the product line or customer team to understand the individual needs of Zebracorp for each particular case.

content.verbatim_text: In those global procurement contracts where the supplier refuses to grant us ownership by default, we should often seek to secure a provision where we agree that Zebracorp or its end customer specific customizations are always owned by Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: For global procurement contracts where suppliers resist default ownership transfer, Zebracorp should aim to include a provision ensuring that Zebracorp-specific or end-customer-specific customizations are always owned by Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This outlines a negotiation strategy for Zebracorp to secure ownership of highly customized or proprietary elements, even if full ownership transfer isn't feasible.
content.conditions: Global procurement contracts where supplier refuses default ownership transfer.
content.justification: Protects Zebracorp's investment in unique customizations and proprietary elements.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must actively negotiate for this specific ownership clause in such scenarios.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be prepared to cede ownership of Zebracorp-specific customizations.
content.text: In those global procurement contracts where the supplier refuses to grant us ownership by default, we should often seek to secure a provision where we agree that Zebracorp or its end customer specific customizations are always owned by Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: “Despite anything to the contrary, the [Buyer] will at all times become the sole and exclusive owner of any and all Intellectual Property Rights in and to any [Buyer] or its end-customer customizations and/or to any or [Service Results] that include, embed or contain or that are based, developed, created or derived from any [Buyer] or its end-customer proprietary design, specifications or intellectual property rights or trade secrets, or that are otherwise based on requirements that are unique or specific to the [Buyer] or to any of its end-customer(s)”.
content.plain_text: An example compromise clause ensures the Buyer (Zebracorp) is the sole owner of all IPRs in customizations specific to the Buyer or its end-customer, or in service results derived from the Buyer's proprietary designs, specifications, IPRs, trade secrets, or unique requirements.
content.expert_insight: This comprehensive clause protects Zebracorp's unique contributions and requirements, ensuring ownership of highly specific adaptations even if general ownership is not transferred.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: “Despite anything to the contrary, the [Buyer] will at all times become the sole and exclusive owner of any and all Intellectual Property Rights in and to any [Buyer] or its end-customer customizations and/or to any or [Service Results] that include, embed or contain or that are based, developed, created or derived from any [Buyer] or its end-customer proprietary design, specifications or intellectual property rights or trade secrets, or that are otherwise based on requirements that are unique or specific to the [Buyer] or to any of its end-customer(s)”.

content.verbatim_text: Note that in cases where we do agree that the supplier/subcontractor retains ownership of the result of the services, it is imperative to agree on our license i.e. right to use those service results that we do not own.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp agrees that a supplier/subcontractor retains ownership of service results, it is essential to secure a license for Zebracorp to use those non-owned results.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical fallback: if ownership isn't secured, a robust license is the next best protection to ensure Zebracorp can still utilize the work it paid for.
content.conditions: Supplier/subcontractor retains ownership of service results.
content.justification: Ensures Zebracorp has legal rights to use deliverables it has paid for but does not own, preventing future claims or restrictions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must always negotiate for a comprehensive license when it doesn't obtain IPR ownership.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers retaining ownership should expect to grant Zebracorp a license to use the service results.
content.text: Note that in cases where we do agree that the supplier/subcontractor retains ownership of the result of the services, it is imperative to agree on our license i.e. right to use those service results that we do not own.

content.verbatim_text: “If and to the extent the ownership of Intellectual Property Rights in the applicable [Results of Services] is not transferred or assigned to or vested with [ZEBRACORP], the [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] and its affiliated entities, a non- exclusive (unless the [Results of Services] are specifically created or developed for [ZEBRACORP] or its endcustomer, in which case ZEBRACORP will obtain an exclusive license), irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide right to use and exploit (including but not limited to the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the applicable [Results of Services]”.
content.plain_text: An example license clause states that if IPR ownership isn't transferred to Zebracorp, the supplier grants Zebracorp and its affiliates a non-exclusive (or exclusive if custom for Zebracorp), irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide right to use and exploit the IPRs in the 'Results of Services', including modification and sublicensing.
content.expert_insight: This is a very strong license clause, providing Zebracorp with extensive rights even without ownership, ensuring broad utility of the deliverables.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: “If and to the extent the ownership of Intellectual Property Rights in the applicable [Results of Services] is not transferred or assigned to or vested with [ZEBRACORP], the [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] and its affiliated entities, a non- exclusive (unless the [Results of Services] are specifically created or developed for [ZEBRACORP] or its endcustomer, in which case ZEBRACORP will obtain an exclusive license), irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide right to use and exploit (including but not limited to the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the applicable [Results of Services]”.

content.verbatim_text: We should be mindful of the fact that the IPR ownership will vest with the creator of the work (this would be the supplier) in case we have not agreed otherwise.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must remember that IPR ownership defaults to the creator (the supplier) if no alternative agreement is made.
content.expert_insight: This serves as a crucial reminder of the default legal position, underscoring the necessity for explicit contractual terms to override it.
content.conditions: No specific agreement on IPR ownership.
content.justification: This is the general legal principle of authorship/inventorship.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp risks not owning IPRs if it fails to explicitly contract for them.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will retain IPRs by default if no agreement is made.
content.text: We should be mindful of the fact that the IPR ownership will vest with the creator of the work (this would be the supplier) in case we have not agreed otherwise.

content.verbatim_text: Unsurprisingly, you may find the suppliers keen to shift the discussion of the IPR ownership to the Statement of Work by proposing to replace the IPR sections of the agreement with a note saying that the IPR ownership will be agreed in a Statement of Work on a case-by-case basis.
content.plain_text: Suppliers often attempt to defer IPR ownership discussions to the Statement of Work (SOW), suggesting it be decided case-by-case, sometimes replacing main agreement IPR sections with a note.
content.expert_insight: This describes a common supplier negotiation tactic to avoid committing to IPR ownership in the main agreement, potentially gaining leverage later.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be wary of this tactic as it can lead to uncertainty and weaker negotiation positions later.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers use this tactic to retain flexibility and potentially better terms for IPRs.
content.text: Unsurprisingly, you may find the suppliers keen to shift the discussion of the IPR ownership to the Statement of Work by proposing to replace the IPR sections of the agreement with a note saying that the IPR ownership will be agreed in a Statement of Work on a case-by-case basis.

content.verbatim_text: While this sounds like an easy option, and while it is certainly true that it is difficult to agree on the ownership of service or development work that we are yet to request, it is nevertheless important to have a fall-back provision that determines the ownership of the IPR in the event the IPR ownership provision is omitted in the Statement of Work.
content.plain_text: Despite the apparent ease of deferring IPR ownership to the SOW, it is crucial to include a fallback provision in the main agreement that defines IPR ownership if it's not addressed in the SOW.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical risk mitigation strategy. Without a fallback, if the SOW is silent, the default 'creator owns' rule would apply, likely to Zebracorp's detriment.
content.conditions: IPR ownership discussions are deferred to the Statement of Work.
content.justification: Prevents IPR ownership from defaulting to the creator (supplier) if SOW is silent, protecting Zebracorp's interests.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure main agreements contain a robust fallback IPR ownership provision.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may face a fallback provision even if they try to defer IPR discussions.
content.text: While this sounds like an easy option, and while it is certainly true that it is difficult to agree on the ownership of service or development work that we are yet to request, it is nevertheless important to have a fall-back provision that determines the ownership of the IPR in the event the IPR ownership provision is omitted in the Statement of Work.

content.verbatim_text: Most likely time and resource constraints will not allow us to start discussion on IPR ownership when entering into a Statement of Work.
content.plain_text: Time and resource limitations will likely prevent detailed IPR ownership negotiations during the SOW phase.
content.expert_insight: This provides a practical reason why deferring IPR discussions to the SOW is problematic: the SOW phase is often too late for complex negotiations.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should handle IPR ownership in the main agreement to avoid rushed or omitted discussions later.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Most likely time and resource constraints will not allow us to start discussion on IPR ownership when entering into a Statement of Work.

content.verbatim_text: A compromise can often be found by laying out the basic rules on the division of IPRs between the supplier and Zebracorp substantially in line with the above mentioned guidelines and by leaving the option to define the ownership in more detail in the Statement of Work or, if necessary, even to deviate from these ground rules in the Statement of Work.
content.plain_text: A compromise involves establishing basic IPR division rules in the main agreement, allowing for more detailed definition or even deviation in the SOW.
content.expert_insight: This offers a pragmatic middle ground: set the framework in the main agreement, then allow flexibility for specifics in the SOW, balancing certainty with adaptability.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this approach to secure general IPR terms while allowing for project-specific adjustments.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may find this a more acceptable approach than rigid IPR terms in the main agreement.
content.text: A compromise can often be found by laying out the basic rules on the division of IPRs between the supplier and Zebracorp substantially in line with the above mentioned guidelines and by leaving the option to define the ownership in more detail in the Statement of Work or, if necessary, even to deviate from these ground rules in the Statement of Work.

content.verbatim_text: It is worth noting that we should generally have no issues with agreeing that the pre-existing intellectual property rights (i.e. IPRs that the supplier already had before commencing to perform the services as per our instructions) will continue to be owned by the supplier even if the supplier elects to embed those pre-existing IPRs into the results of services that the supplier surrenders over to us upon the completion of the services.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should generally agree that suppliers retain ownership of their pre-existing IPRs, even if these are incorporated into the service results delivered to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This is standard practice: pre-existing IP typically remains with its original owner. Zebracorp's focus should be on securing a license for its use, not ownership.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should not generally seek ownership of supplier's pre-existing IPRs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can expect to retain ownership of their pre-existing IPRs.
content.text: It is worth noting that we should generally have no issues with agreeing that the pre-existing intellectual property rights (i.e. IPRs that the supplier already had before commencing to perform the services as per our instructions) will continue to be owned by the supplier even if the supplier elects to embed those pre-existing IPRs into the results of services that the supplier surrenders over to us upon the completion of the services.

content.verbatim_text: Our procurement contract templates address this issue by having language saying: “[ZEBRACORP] acknowledges that the copyright and ownership in any materials produced by the [Supplier] prior to and in no relation to the execution of the [Services] shall remain vested with the [Supplier]” or its variants.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's procurement templates include language acknowledging that copyright and ownership of supplier materials created prior to and unrelated to the services remain with the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This shows how Zebracorp's standard contracts explicitly address and confirm the supplier's retention of pre-existing IP.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Our procurement contract templates address this issue by having language saying: “[ZEBRACORP] acknowledges that the copyright and ownership in any materials produced by the [Supplier] prior to and in no relation to the execution of the [Services] shall remain vested with the [Supplier]” or its variants.

content.verbatim_text: The phrase “…prior to and in no relation to…” in the above sentence can often be negotiated to “…prior to or in no relation to…”.
content.plain_text: The phrase 'prior to and in no relation to' in the pre-existing IPR clause is often negotiable to 'prior to or in no relation to'.
content.expert_insight: This is a subtle but important negotiation point. Changing 'and' to 'or' broadens the scope of what is considered supplier pre-existing IP, potentially favoring the supplier.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be aware of this negotiation point and its implications for the scope of pre-existing IPR.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can seek this change to ensure broader protection for their pre-existing IP.
content.text: The phrase “…prior to and in no relation to…” in the above sentence can often be negotiated to “…prior to or in no relation to…”.

content.verbatim_text: However, we must have a license to use these pre-existing IPRs.
content.plain_text: It is mandatory for Zebracorp to obtain a license to use any pre-existing IPRs belonging to the supplier that are incorporated into the deliverables.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical requirement. Even if Zebracorp doesn't own the pre-existing IP, it absolutely needs a license to legally use the final deliverables that contain it.
content.conditions: Supplier's pre-existing IPRs are embedded into the results of services.
content.justification: Ensures Zebracorp has the legal right to use the full deliverables without infringing on supplier's pre-existing IPRs.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must always secure a license for embedded pre-existing IPRs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must grant a license for their pre-existing IPRs embedded in deliverables.
content.text: However, we must have a license to use these pre-existing IPRs.

content.verbatim_text: In the absence of such license the supplier could potentially later claim royalties or license fees for our use of the results of the services.
content.plain_text: Without a license, the supplier could later demand royalties or license fees for Zebracorp's use of the service results that incorporate their pre-existing IPRs.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the financial and legal risk of not securing a license for embedded pre-existing IP.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp faces potential unexpected costs and legal disputes if a license is not secured.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers could potentially monetize their pre-existing IPRs if Zebracorp fails to secure a license.
content.text: In the absence of such license the supplier could potentially later claim royalties or license fees for our use of the results of the services.

content.verbatim_text: “The [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide and unlimited right to use and exploit in any possible manner (including but not limited the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the such pre-existing copyrights if and to the extent such pre-existing copyrights are necessary for [ZEBRACORP] for the purpose of exploiting the [Results of Services] procured pursuant to this [Agreement], and the [Supplier] warrants with respect to its representatives and any third party engaged to the performance of the [Professional Services] on behalf of the [Supplier] under this [Agreement], that they will do the same.”
content.plain_text: An example license for pre-existing IPRs grants Zebracorp an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide, and unlimited right to use and exploit such IPRs, if necessary for exploiting the 'Results of Services', with the supplier warranting compliance from its representatives and third parties.
content.expert_insight: This is a very strong license clause for Zebracorp, providing comprehensive rights to use embedded pre-existing IP, ensuring full utility of the final deliverables.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: “The [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide and unlimited right to use and exploit in any possible manner (including but not limited the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the such pre-existing copyrights if and to the extent such pre-existing copyrights are necessary for [ZEBRACORP] for the purpose of exploiting the [Results of Services] procured pursuant to this [Agreement], and the [Supplier] warrants with respect to its representatives and any third party engaged to the performance of the [Professional Services] on behalf of the [Supplier] under this [Agreement], that they will do the same.”

content.verbatim_text: The term ‘warrants’ at the end of the above clause can be changed to less stringent word such as ‘shall ensure’ or this warranty can be negotiated away be entirely removing the last bit that starts with: “….and the [Supplier] warrants…”.
content.plain_text: The term 'warrants' in the license clause can be softened to 'shall ensure' or entirely removed through negotiation.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a specific negotiation point for suppliers to reduce their liability or commitment regarding third-party compliance with the license.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be aware that suppliers may seek to weaken this warranty.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can negotiate to reduce the stringency of the warranty clause.
content.text: The term ‘warrants’ at the end of the above clause can be changed to less stringent word such as ‘shall ensure’ or this warranty can be negotiated away be entirely removing the last bit that starts with: “….and the [Supplier] warrants…”.

content.verbatim_text: The above clause provides additional room for negotiation. The license does not need to be unlimited but it can in fact be specifically labelled as a limited license. Also the license is not required to be exclusive but we can in most cases readily consent to the above license being ‘non-exclusive’ i.e. allow the supplier to license the same pre-existing IPRs to its other customers as well.
content.plain_text: The license clause offers further negotiation points: it can be limited in scope rather than unlimited, and Zebracorp can agree to a non-exclusive license, allowing the supplier to license the same pre-existing IPRs to other customers.
content.expert_insight: This provides Zebracorp with flexibility to concede on exclusivity or scope if it doesn't need maximum rights, potentially achieving better commercial terms.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can negotiate for a more tailored license if an unlimited, exclusive one is not required.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can negotiate for non-exclusive or limited licenses for their pre-existing IPRs, allowing them to reuse assets.
content.text: The above clause provides additional room for negotiation. The license does not need to be unlimited but it can in fact be specifically labelled as a limited license. Also the license is not required to be exclusive but we can in most cases readily consent to the above license being ‘non-exclusive’ i.e. allow the supplier to license the same pre-existing IPRs to its other customers as well.

content.verbatim_text: Unless Zebracorp obtains full ownership to any and all IPRs in the deliverables, no matter when created, it is advisable to insert a clause into the [development] agreement that supplier has no right to include any pre-existing IPR into the deliverables/Zebracorp product unless otherwise expressly agreed in writing.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp does not obtain full ownership of all IPRs in deliverables, it is advisable to include a clause in the development agreement preventing the supplier from incorporating any pre-existing IPRs into the deliverables/Zebracorp product unless explicitly agreed in writing.
content.expert_insight: This is a preventative measure to avoid future disputes over embedded pre-existing IP, especially if Zebracorp aims for full ownership of the deliverables.
content.conditions: Zebracorp does not obtain full IPR ownership in deliverables.
content.justification: Prevents supplier from asserting IP claims on Zebracorp products due to embedded pre-existing IPR, reducing risk.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should proactively include this restrictive clause in development agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers would be restricted from embedding their pre-existing IPRs without explicit written consent.
content.text: Unless Zebracorp obtains full ownership to any and all IPRs in the deliverables, no matter when created, it is advisable to insert a clause into the [development] agreement that supplier has no right to include any pre-existing IPR into the deliverables/Zebracorp product unless otherwise expressly agreed in writing.

content.verbatim_text: This is to avoid any cases where the supplier might later assert IP ownership claim into certain part of Zebracorp product due to fact that Zebracorp product contains supplier pre-existing IPR.
content.plain_text: This clause aims to prevent future IP ownership claims by the supplier over parts of a Zebracorp product that might contain the supplier's pre-existing IPR.
content.expert_insight: This explains the risk mitigation purpose of the previous guideline, preventing 'Trojan horse' IP claims.

content.verbatim_text: Whilst some of our contract templates may simply talk about any adaptations (see in e.g. section 11.3 of the Software License Agreement for Applications), we can specify which adaptations Zebracorp intends to make.

content.text: This potential bone of contention can often be resolved by defining the Zebracorp adaptation in sufficient detail and by adding clarifying language such as: “the foregoing will not be construed to transfer or assign any ownership or title to any intellectual property rights of the supplier in the underlying product but the supplier and its licensors will retain all such rights despite any adaptations made by or for [ZEBRACORP]“, or similar wording to safeguard supplier’s IP ownership in the underlying product.

content.verbatim_text: Note that if Zebracorp provides any specifications or copyrighted material to the supplier, it is important to also mention that Zebracorp’s ownership rights extend to any modifications or further development of any of those Zebracorp materials and information.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp provides specifications or copyrighted material to a supplier, it's important to specify that Zebracorp's ownership rights also cover any modifications or further developments of those materials.
content.expert_insight: This is crucial for protecting Zebracorp's pre-existing IP. Without this, a supplier could modify Zebracorp's materials and claim ownership of the derivative work.
content.conditions: Zebracorp provides specifications or copyrighted material to a supplier.
content.justification: Prevents suppliers from claiming ownership over modified versions of Zebracorp's proprietary materials.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must include this clause to protect its IPRs in derivative works created by suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must acknowledge Zebracorp's ownership of derivative works based on Zebracorp's materials.
content.text: Note that if Zebracorp provides any specifications or copyrighted material to the supplier, it is important to also mention that Zebracorp’s ownership rights extend to any modifications or further development of any of those Zebracorp materials and information.

content.verbatim_text: Should we fail to assert our rights also to these modifications or derivative works, there is a risk that the supplier/subcontractor might modify our copyrighted materials and subsequently claim copyright to the “new” modified work.
content.plain_text: Failing to assert rights over modifications or derivative works of Zebracorp's copyrighted materials risks the supplier/subcontractor claiming copyright to the modified work.
content.expert_insight: This explains the specific risk associated with not addressing ownership of derivative works based on Zebracorp's IP.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp faces a risk of losing IPRs to derivative works if it doesn't assert its rights.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers could potentially claim copyright to modified works if Zebracorp's rights are not asserted.
content.text: Should we fail to assert our rights also to these modifications or derivative works, there is a risk that the supplier/subcontractor might modify our copyrighted materials and subsequently claim copyright to the “new” modified work.

content.verbatim_text: In development contracts it is fairly customary to specify in detail which party becomes the owner of the results of the development work.
content.plain_text: In development contracts, it is standard practice to explicitly detail which party will own the intellectual property resulting from the development work.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the critical importance of IPR clauses in development agreements, where new IP is the primary output.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should expect and prepare for detailed IPR ownership discussions in development contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect detailed IPR ownership clauses in development contracts.
content.text: In development contracts it is fairly customary to specify in detail which party becomes the owner of the results of the development work.

content.verbatim_text: The intellectual property that is created as part of the development is typically referred to as ‘foreground IPRs’, ‘results of development’ or similarly, whereas the existing intellectual property that the developer embeds or incorporates into the results of development are generally referred to ‘background IPRs’ or ‘pre-existing IPRs’.
content.plain_text: IP created during development is called 'foreground IPRs' or 'results of development', while existing IP incorporated by the developer is termed 'background IPRs' or 'pre-existing IPRs'.
content.expert_insight: This provides essential terminology for distinguishing between newly created IP and pre-existing IP in development contexts, crucial for clear contractual drafting.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: The intellectual property that is created as part of the development is typically referred to as ‘foreground IPRs’, ‘results of development’ or similarly, whereas the existing intellectual property that the developer embeds or incorporates into the results of development are generally referred to ‘background IPRs’ or ‘pre-existing IPRs’.

content.verbatim_text: Foreground IPRs can be owned by either Zebracorp or the developer depending on the requirements of Zebracorp; this means that we should consider if we can allow the developer to sell the products to parties other than Zebracorp .
content.plain_text: Ownership of foreground IPRs can be assigned to either Zebracorp or the developer, based on Zebracorp's needs, which includes considering whether the developer can sell the products to other parties.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the flexibility in foreground IPR ownership but links it directly to Zebracorp's commercial strategy and exclusivity needs.
content.conditions: Determining ownership of foreground IPRs in development agreements.
content.justification: Aligns IPR ownership with Zebracorp's strategic and commercial requirements.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must carefully assess its needs for exclusivity and control over foreground IPRs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may negotiate to retain ownership of foreground IPRs if Zebracorp allows for broader commercialization.
content.text: Foreground IPRs can be owned by either Zebracorp or the developer depending on the requirements of Zebracorp; this means that we should consider if we can allow the developer to sell the products to parties other than Zebracorp .

content.verbatim_text: The ownership should be checked with the respective product owner (product line/product management).
content.plain_text: IPR ownership decisions must be verified with the relevant product owner (e.g., product line or product management).
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes internal alignment: legal teams should consult with business stakeholders to ensure IPR strategy supports product goals.
content.conditions: Determining IPR ownership in development agreements.
content.justification: Ensures IPR strategy aligns with product development and commercialization plans.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's legal and procurement teams must consult product owners.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: The ownership should be checked with the respective product owner (product line/product management).

content.verbatim_text: Also in cases where Zebracorp pays for the development work, Zebracorp should as a baseline acquire full unrestricted ownership.
content.plain_text: As a baseline, when Zebracorp funds development work, it should obtain full, unrestricted ownership of the resulting IPRs.
content.expert_insight: This establishes Zebracorp's strong default position: 'he who pays' should get full ownership, especially for commissioned development.
content.conditions: Zebracorp pays for development work.
content.justification: Secures Zebracorp's investment and provides maximum control over the developed IP.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must prioritize negotiating for full, unrestricted ownership in these scenarios.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to seek full IPR ownership when funding development.
content.text: Also in cases where Zebracorp pays for the development work, Zebracorp should as a baseline acquire full unrestricted ownership.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever we agree that Zebracorp does not become the owner of the foreground IPR, we should agree on a broad license (i.e. the right to use) that Zebracorp obtains into such foreground IPR.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp does not acquire ownership of foreground IPR, it must secure a broad license (right to use) for that foreground IPR.
content.expert_insight: This is the critical fallback if ownership isn't achieved: ensure a comprehensive license to enable full use of the developed IP.
content.conditions: Zebracorp does not become the owner of foreground IPR.
content.justification: Ensures Zebracorp has the necessary rights to use and exploit the developed IP, even without ownership.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must prioritize negotiating for a broad license if ownership is not secured.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers retaining ownership of foreground IPR should expect to grant Zebracorp a broad license.
content.text: Whenever we agree that Zebracorp does not become the owner of the foreground IPR, we should agree on a broad license (i.e. the right to use) that Zebracorp obtains into such foreground IPR.

content.verbatim_text: Such licenses can often be exclusive which mean that only Zebracorp will have the right to use foreground works and the developer is prevented from licensing the foreground IPR to its other customers.
content.plain_text: These licenses can frequently be exclusive, granting Zebracorp sole rights to use the foreground works and preventing the developer from licensing them to other clients.
content.expert_insight: This describes the most protective type of license for Zebracorp, offering near-ownership control without actual ownership.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can seek exclusive licenses for foreground IPRs to maintain competitive advantage.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers granting exclusive licenses lose the ability to commercialize foreground IPRs with other customers.
content.text: Such licenses can often be exclusive which mean that only Zebracorp will have the right to use foreground works and the developer is prevented from licensing the foreground IPR to its other customers.

content.verbatim_text: However, the license can also be nonexclusive depending on our case specific requirements.
content.plain_text: Alternatively, the license can be non-exclusive, depending on Zebracorp's specific needs for the case.
content.expert_insight: This offers flexibility, allowing Zebracorp to accept a non-exclusive license if its needs don't require exclusivity, potentially reducing costs.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can opt for a non-exclusive license if exclusivity is not a priority.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers prefer non-exclusive licenses as it allows them to reuse and monetize IP with other clients.
content.text: However, the license can also be nonexclusive depending on our case specific requirements.

content.verbatim_text: In any event it is important to make sure that license is sufficiently broad/comprehensive to give us the rights we need to exploit the results of development in the manner that we had contemplated.
content.plain_text: Regardless of exclusivity, it is crucial to ensure the license is broad and comprehensive enough to allow Zebracorp to exploit the development results as intended.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the importance of scope and clarity in licensing, ensuring no unintended restrictions hinder Zebracorp's use of the developed IP.
content.conditions: Securing a license for foreground IPRs.
content.justification: Ensures Zebracorp can fully utilize the developed IP for its intended business purposes.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must carefully review license terms to ensure they meet its operational needs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be prepared to grant a license that is sufficiently broad for Zebracorp's intended use.
content.text: In any event it is important to make sure that license is sufficiently broad/comprehensive to give us the rights we need to exploit the results of development in the manner that we had contemplated.

content.verbatim_text: As for the background IPRs, Zebracorp will generally only require a license to use such background IP.
content.plain_text: For background IPRs, Zebracorp typically only needs a license to use them, not ownership.
content.expert_insight: This is a pragmatic approach for background IP, recognizing that it's usually pre-existing and core to the supplier's business, so a license for use within the project context is sufficient.
content.conditions: Dealing with supplier's background IPRs.
content.justification: Allows Zebracorp to utilize the deliverables without needing to own the supplier's core IP.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should focus on securing appropriate licenses for background IPRs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can expect to retain ownership of their background IPRs, granting Zebracorp a license.
content.text: As for the background IPRs, Zebracorp will generally only require a license to use such background IP.

content.verbatim_text: This license can be limited in the sense that the license is only granted for the purposes of enabling Zebracorp to make use of the results of development.
content.plain_text: This license for background IPRs can be limited, granted solely for the purpose of enabling Zebracorp to use the development results.
content.expert_insight: This describes a common scope for background IP licenses, ensuring Zebracorp can use the final product without gaining broader rights to the supplier's core technology.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure the limited license for background IPRs is sufficient for its intended use of the deliverables.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can offer limited licenses for their background IPRs, protecting their broader commercialization rights.
content.text: This license can be limited in the sense that the license is only granted for the purposes of enabling Zebracorp to make use of the results of development.

content.verbatim_text: The license to this background IPR is typically non-exclusive meaning that the developer can license the same background IPR also to its other customers.
content.plain_text: Licenses for background IPRs are usually non-exclusive, allowing the developer to license the same IP to other clients.
content.expert_insight: This is standard for background IP, as it allows suppliers to leverage their core technology across multiple projects and customers.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should expect non-exclusive licenses for background IPRs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers typically prefer non-exclusive licenses for their background IPRs to maximize commercial opportunities.
content.text: The license to this background IPR is typically non-exclusive meaning that the developer can license the same background IPR also to its other customers.

content.verbatim_text: In case the development work includes the implementation of any Zebracorp proprietary items, Zebracorp should retain IPR ownership to such proprietary items as default, without any license to the supplier.
content.plain_text: If development work involves implementing Zebracorp's proprietary items, Zebracorp should, by default, retain IPR ownership of these items, without granting any license to the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical protection for Zebracorp's core proprietary assets, ensuring they remain exclusively Zebracorp's, even if a supplier works with them.
content.conditions: Development work includes implementation of Zebracorp proprietary items.
content.justification: Protects Zebracorp's unique and specific intellectual property from unauthorized use or commercialization by suppliers.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure contracts explicitly state its retention of IPR ownership for its proprietary items.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must acknowledge Zebracorp's exclusive ownership of its proprietary items and not expect licenses for them.
content.text: In case the development work includes the implementation of any Zebracorp proprietary items, Zebracorp should retain IPR ownership to such proprietary items as default, without any license to the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: These proprietary items are typically very Zebracorp specific requirements, which we cannot permit or allow the supplier to sell (once implemented) to any parties other than Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: These proprietary items are usually unique to Zebracorp and cannot be sold by the supplier to other parties after implementation.
content.expert_insight: This provides the commercial rationale for Zebracorp's strict ownership stance on its proprietary items: they are unique and non-transferable to competitors.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: These proprietary items are typically very Zebracorp specific requirements, which we cannot permit or allow the supplier to sell (once implemented) to any parties other than Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: An example of such Zebracorp proprietary items is the interface between the remote system and the system module.
content.plain_text: An example of a Zebracorp proprietary item is the interface connecting a remote system and a system module.
content.expert_insight: This provides a concrete example of the type of specific, unique IP Zebracorp would want to retain exclusive ownership of.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: An example of such Zebracorp proprietary items is the interface between the remote system and the system module.

content.verbatim_text: While joint ownership of IPR that is generated through collaborative development may seem a fair solution, joint ownership can result on difficulties when the parties seek to use exploit the IPR in the future.
content.plain_text: Although joint IPR ownership from collaborative development appears equitable, it often leads to future complications when parties try to use or exploit the IPR.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a common pitfall of joint ownership: while seemingly fair, it often creates practical difficulties in commercialization and management.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be aware of the potential difficulties arising from joint IPR ownership.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should also be aware of the complexities of joint IPR ownership.
content.text: While joint ownership of IPR that is generated through collaborative development may seem a fair solution, joint ownership can result on difficulties when the parties seek to use exploit the IPR in the future.

content.verbatim_text: This may mean that a joint decision is required by both co-owners for licensing of the intellectual property rights.
content.plain_text: Joint ownership can necessitate mutual decisions from both co-owners for any licensing of the intellectual property rights.
content.expert_insight: This is a direct consequence of joint ownership, potentially leading to deadlocks if co-owners disagree on licensing strategy.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp may face delays or inability to license jointly owned IPR if the co-owner disagrees.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may also face restrictions on licensing jointly owned IPR.
content.text: This may mean that a joint decision is required by both co-owners for licensing of the intellectual property rights.

content.verbatim_text: As for patentable inventions, the filing or maintaining/selling of patent application and prosecution of a patent is likely to become very complicated when the patentable invention is jointly owned.
content.plain_text: Joint ownership of patentable inventions can significantly complicate the process of filing, maintaining, selling, and prosecuting patent applications.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the specific administrative and strategic complexities of jointly owned patents, making them particularly difficult to manage.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp would face increased administrative burden and potential disputes for jointly owned patents.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers would also experience complications in managing jointly owned patents.
content.text: As for patentable inventions, the filing or maintaining/selling of patent application and prosecution of a patent is likely to become very complicated when the patentable invention is jointly owned.

content.verbatim_text: It is advisable to avoid jointly owned intellectual property rights.
content.plain_text: It is recommended to avoid joint ownership of intellectual property rights.
content.expert_insight: This is a strong recommendation against joint ownership due to its inherent complexities and potential for conflict.
content.conditions: Considering IPR ownership models in collaborative development.
content.justification: Joint ownership creates management difficulties, potential for deadlock, and complications in exploitation and enforcement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should actively seek alternatives to joint IPR ownership.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should also be cautious about entering into joint IPR ownership agreements.
content.text: It is advisable to avoid jointly owned intellectual property rights.

content.verbatim_text: This is particularly true if the development work/collaboration can result in patentable inventions.
content.plain_text: This advice is especially pertinent when collaborative development might lead to patentable inventions.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes that the complexities of joint ownership are magnified when dealing with patents, due to their formal requirements.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: This is particularly true if the development work/collaboration can result in patentable inventions.

content.verbatim_text: Often a better solution is achieved through agreeing on one party owning all of the intellectual property generated as a result of the collaborative innovation/development and on licensing it to the other party on a free-of-charge perpetual basis and with sufficiently broad license terms.
content.plain_text: A superior alternative to joint ownership is for one party to own all generated IP from collaboration, then license it to the other party on a free, perpetual, and broadly defined basis.
content.expert_insight: This offers a practical and often preferred alternative to joint ownership, providing clarity of ownership while ensuring both parties can still utilize the IP.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can pursue this model to gain clear ownership while providing necessary usage rights to collaborators.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might accept this model if they receive a broad, free license for the IP they helped create.
content.text: Often a better solution is achieved through agreeing on one party owning all of the intellectual property generated as a result of the collaborative innovation/development and on licensing it to the other party on a free-of-charge perpetual basis and with sufficiently broad license terms.

content.verbatim_text: As an alternative the portfolio of intellectual property created may be divided out between the parties, based on the vested interests of each party.
content.plain_text: Another option is to divide the created IP portfolio between the parties according to their respective vested interests.
content.expert_insight: This presents another alternative to joint ownership, suitable when different components of the IP are more relevant to one party's core business than the other's.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can seek to own IP components most relevant to its business.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can seek to own IP components most relevant to their business.
content.text: As an alternative the portfolio of intellectual property created may be divided out between the parties, based on the vested interests of each party.

content.verbatim_text: It should be noted that it is very seldom that Zebracorp performs any real collaborative development of a product together with an external third party; the “collaboration” with suppliers under any agreement should not be confused with “joint development”.
content.plain_text: It's rare for Zebracorp to engage in true collaborative product development with external third parties; 'collaboration' with suppliers should not be mistaken for 'joint development'.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies Zebracorp's typical engagement model, distinguishing between standard supplier relationships and more intensive joint development, which has different IPR implications.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be clear about the nature of its 'collaboration' to avoid unintended joint ownership implications.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should understand that their 'collaboration' with Zebracorp is usually not 'joint development' in the IP sense.
content.text: It should be noted that it is very seldom that Zebracorp performs any real collaborative development of a product together with an external third party; the “collaboration” with suppliers under any agreement should not be confused with “joint development”.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s own existing intellectual property rights should never be transferred, assigned or sold in an ordinary procurement contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's existing intellectual property rights must never be transferred, assigned, or sold within a standard procurement contract.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental, non-negotiable rule for Zebracorp to protect its core assets. Procurement contracts are for acquiring goods/services, not divesting Zebracorp's IP.
content.conditions: Ordinary procurement contracts.
content.justification: Protects Zebracorp's core intellectual property from unintended transfer or loss.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp personnel must ensure no such transfers occur in procurement contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should not expect to acquire Zebracorp's existing IPRs through ordinary procurement contracts.
content.text: Zebracorp’s own existing intellectual property rights should never be transferred, assigned or sold in an ordinary procurement contract.

content.verbatim_text: At most we can consider granting limited licenses to use certain specified Zebracorp IPR for the purpose of performing the supplier/subcontractor’s obligations towards Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: At most, Zebracorp may consider granting limited licenses for specific Zebracorp IPRs, strictly for the purpose of enabling a supplier/subcontractor to fulfill their obligations to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This defines the maximum permissible use of Zebracorp's IP by suppliers: a restricted license for functional purposes only.
content.conditions: Supplier/subcontractor needs to use Zebracorp IPR to perform obligations.
content.justification: Allows suppliers to perform services while safeguarding Zebracorp's IPR ownership and broader exploitation rights.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should only grant limited, purpose-specific licenses for its IPRs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may receive limited licenses to Zebracorp IPR strictly for contract performance.
content.text: At most we can consider granting limited licenses to use certain specified Zebracorp IPR for the purpose of performing the supplier/subcontractor’s obligations towards Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: In such event it is worthwhile specifying that the license is limited, non-exclusive, revocable, and granted solely for such purpose, and for no other purpose whatsoever.
content.plain_text: When granting such a license, it is important to specify that it is limited, non-exclusive, revocable, and granted strictly for the stated purpose, with no other uses permitted.
content.expert_insight: This specifies the key characteristics of a protective license for Zebracorp's IP, ensuring minimal risk and maximum control.
content.conditions: Granting a license to Zebracorp IPR to a supplier/subcontractor.
content.justification: Minimizes risk of unauthorized use or exploitation of Zebracorp's IPR by the supplier.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure these protective terms are included in any license for its IPR.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers receiving such licenses must adhere strictly to these limitations.
content.text: In such event it is worthwhile specifying that the license is limited, non-exclusive, revocable, and granted solely for such purpose, and for no other purpose whatsoever.

content.verbatim_text: Where needed, please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team to assist with the correct wording.
content.plain_text: If precise wording is required, consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team for assistance.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the importance of legal expertise for drafting sensitive IPR clauses, ensuring accuracy and enforceability.
content.conditions: Drafting IPR clauses, especially for Zebracorp's IPR.
content.justification: Ensures legal accuracy and minimizes risk of errors in critical contractual language.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp personnel should seek legal counsel for IPR wording.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Where needed, please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team to assist with the correct wording.

content.verbatim_text: Any other license to Zebracorp IPR should be subject to a separate written license agreement.
content.plain_text: Any license for Zebracorp IPR that falls outside the limited, purpose-specific scope must be formalized in a separate written license agreement.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a formal process for any broader licensing of Zebracorp's IP, ensuring proper documentation and review.
content.conditions: Granting any license to Zebracorp IPR beyond limited, purpose-specific use in a procurement contract.
content.justification: Ensures proper legal review and documentation for significant IPR licenses, protecting Zebracorp's assets.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must follow this formal process for broader IPR licenses.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers seeking broader licenses to Zebracorp IPR should expect a separate, dedicated agreement.
content.text: Any other license to Zebracorp IPR should be subject to a separate written license agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Care should be taken with Feedback and Residuals clauses, as the suppliers quite often expect to get a full license (including patents) in particular to the Feedback (see the Confidentiality Clause in this document).
content.plain_text: Exercise caution with Feedback and Residuals clauses, as suppliers frequently anticipate a full license, including patent rights, especially concerning feedback provided.
content.expert_insight: This warns Zebracorp about a common area where suppliers seek to acquire rights to Zebracorp's IP (feedback), which can be valuable.
content.conditions: Drafting or reviewing Feedback and Residuals clauses.
content.justification: Prevents unintended transfer of valuable IPRs (e.g., patents on feedback) to suppliers.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must carefully scrutinize these clauses to avoid inadvertently granting broad licenses.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers often seek broad licenses for feedback and residuals.
content.text: Care should be taken with Feedback and Residuals clauses, as the suppliers quite often expect to get a full license (including patents) in particular to the Feedback (see the Confidentiality Clause in this document).

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s preferred position on IPR ownership depends the nature of the contract and products and services we are looking to acquire.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's preferred stance on IPR ownership is flexible and determined by the specific contract type and the nature of the products and services being acquired.
content.expert_insight: This reiterates the need for a tailored approach to IPR, acknowledging that a 'one-size-fits-all' strategy is impractical.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must evaluate its IPR strategy on a case-by-case basis.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that Zebracorp's IPR demands will vary by contract.
content.text: Zebracorp’s preferred position on IPR ownership depends the nature of the contract and products and services we are looking to acquire.

content.verbatim_text: In most contracts it is sufficient to say that each party retains its and its licensors IPRs and that there is no transfer of any IPRs from one party to the other.
content.plain_text: For most contracts, it is adequate to state that each party and their licensors retain their respective IPRs, with no transfer occurring between parties.
content.expert_insight: This describes the common default position for IPRs in many contracts, indicating that a simple retention clause is often sufficient.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this simple clause for contracts where new IPR is not being created or transferred.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will find this a common and acceptable clause in many contracts.
content.text: In most contracts it is sufficient to say that each party retains its and its licensors IPRs and that there is no transfer of any IPRs from one party to the other.

content.verbatim_text: The above does not apply to any development agreements where it is in fact mandatory to agree specifically which party will become the owner of the results of the development and how pre-existing IPR will be treated.
content.plain_text: This general approach does not apply to development agreements, where it is mandatory to explicitly agree on the ownership of development results and the treatment of pre-existing IPRs.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical exception to the general rule, emphasizing that development agreements require specific, detailed IPR clauses due to the creation of new IP.
content.conditions: Development agreements.
content.justification: Development agreements involve the creation of new IP, necessitating clear ownership and treatment of pre-existing IP to prevent disputes.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure detailed IPR clauses are included in all development agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers in development agreements must be prepared for specific IPR negotiations.
content.text: The above does not apply to any development agreements where it is in fact mandatory to agree specifically which party will become the owner of the results of the development and how pre-existing IPR will be treated.

content.verbatim_text: Any material deviations and variations to the terms to the IPR provisions of the respective Zebracorp development agreements templates are recommended to be reviewed by Legal & Compliance.
content.plain_text: Any significant changes or deviations from the IPR provisions in Zebracorp's development agreement templates should be reviewed by the Legal & Compliance team.
content.expert_insight: This ensures that any customization of critical IPR clauses receives expert legal scrutiny, mitigating risks associated with non-standard terms.
content.conditions: Material deviations or variations to IPR provisions in Zebracorp development agreement templates.
content.justification: Ensures legal soundness, risk mitigation, and consistency with Zebracorp's IPR strategy.
